aboutUs.description: Within the framework of the policy of the Ministry and the Agency to implement the state’s directives to expedite the provision of services provided to investors, and within the framework of improving the quality of services provided by the Coal Unit to encourage investment and not disrupt investors, the decision of Mr. Dr., CEO of the Agency No. (1042) was issued on 10/19/2022 to add a clause Resolution No. (185) of 2018 regulating the documentary cycle stipulates that the duration of this cycle be determined to be two working days instead of three working days, starting from the date the documents are completed and the company pays the administrative expenses and legally prescribed fees.

swiper.swiperText: An integrated system for obtaining licenses, approvals and permits for coal trading activities.

admissionSteps.title: Admission steps
admissionSteps.description: To obtain the service, follow the following steps
admissionSteps.mainText: You can now use an electronic signature during registration to ensure the integrity of the procedures

firstCard.title: 1 - Data recording
firstCard.description: The authorized person creates an account for the facility by entering the data for himself and the facility and verifying this data through the company’s electronic signature and submitting the required documents for that.

secondCard.title: 2 - Service Request
secondCard.description: After creating the account and registering the facility, the authorized person submits a request to obtain approval or license through the system.

thirdCard.title: 3 - Payment of fees
thirdCard.description: The authorized person pays the fees online through the system.

fourthCard.title: 4 - Issuing permits
fourthCard.description: The head of the agency reviews the data and issues approval or authorization through the system.

report1.title: Shipping and Unloading Companies at Maritime and River Ports
report1.text1: Shipping and unloading companies dealing with coal and petroleum coke must obtain an environmental approval based on either: an Environmental Compatibility Plan (CPA) for existing companies handling harmful bulk shipments, or an Environmental Impact Assessment for new companies in this field.
report1.text2: While approval can be obtained once, it can be revoked due to non-compliance with environmental regulations. Companies are required to submit an annual performance report to assess their interim performance every two years. The technical committee formed by ministerial decision is responsible for reviewing performance reports and evaluating performance based on two consecutive performance reports, then issuing a decision.
report1.subTitle: Equipment Used in Loading and Unloading Ships
report1.text3: Advanced companies, to obtain approvals for unloading ships at the quay, must also obtain approval for unloading at the port, as unloading at the quay is an exception. If the waiting line for unloading at the quay is too long or the water depth is not suitable for the ship's draft, a certificate assessing the environmental impact is required.
report1.text4: Companies applying for approvals to unload at the port quay must submit an environmental impact assessment. If they have just started unloading harmful bulk shipments, companies previously involved in unloading harmful bulk shipments and holding a permit to do so from the port authorities must submit an Environmental Compatibility Plan including approvals in both cases on a list of the equipment that will be used and their specifications. The following table should be filled out.
report1.noReason: If not available, specify the reason
report1.item1: Use of heavy polyethylene fiber tarpaulin to cover the distance between the quay and the ship to prevent water pollution
report1.item2: Use of water spraying machines during unloading to prevent dust emissions from coal
report1.item3: Use of scrubbers to clean the water surface from coal dust to clean the water
report1.item4: Use of water spraying machines on loaded coal above trucks to prevent hot spots formation
report1.item5: Cleaning the quay after unloading for service and cleaning
report1.item6: Unloading directly into trucks or conveyor belts to reduce emissions resulting from reloading the load onto trucks
report1.item7: Use of water spraying machines on coal in storage areas to prevent hot spots formation
report1.item8: Use of covered conveyor belts to reduce air emissions
report1.subTitle2: Compliance Status for Storage at Ports
report1.subTitle2Text: Storage at ports may be in open areas or in closed stores.
report1.item9: Preparation of reports on storage in open areas
report1.item10: Height of the coal pile < 9 meters to reduce hot spots formation
report1.item11: Height of uncompressed coal pile < 5 meters to reduce hot spots formation
report1.item12: Use of water spraying machines to extinguish hot spots
report1.item13: Preparation of reports on storage in closed stores
report1.item14: Monitoring of carbon monoxide levels for early detection of hot spots
report1.item15: Good ventilation to reduce air pollutant concentrations
report1.item16: Use of fabric filters to reduce air emissions
report1.item17: Preparation of reports on storage period (not to exceed one month)
report1.item18: Please attach a cargo statement including shipment data
report1.subTitle3Text: In this regard, the company is required to report violations detected during inspections carried out by the environmental affairs device, fines paid, as well as non-compliance issues and corrective actions
report1.subTitle4Text: Trucking companies must obtain an environmental approval from a competent authority that the company will comply with the environmental regulations issued by the Environmental Affairs Agency. The company will comply with the environmental regulations issued by the Environmental Affairs Agency. The company will comply with the environmental regulations issued by the Environmental Affairs Agency.

report2.title: Coal and Petroleum Road Transport Companies
report2.subTitle: General Requirements for Coal and Petroleum Transport
report2.subTitleText: The following observations are to be fulfilled and accompanied by photocopies of documents certified by the companies and photos from the field.
report2.firstParagraph: The company is committed to transporting coal and petroleum through a shipping and unloading company that has obtained an environmental approval to any facility using coal or intermediate stores or to maritime ports or river marina quays that have obtained an environmental approval.
report2.item1: Requirements and Standards for Transport Trucks
report2.item5: Are the company's vehicles licensed by the relevant authorities?
report2.item6: Is the coal tightly covered to prevent its scattering or dust leakage during transport?
report2.item7: Is the truck's capacity adhered to by weighing it on a scale?
report2.item8: Is the traffic plan followed, showing the agreed-upon traffic lanes with the employing company?
report2.item9: Is the cargo sprayed with sprayed water or chemicals to help reduce emissions before leaving the storage yards?
report2.item10: Are precautions taken and international hazard signs placed to clarify the danger level, and are the phone numbers for complaints specified on each coal-carrying truck?
report2.item11: Has permission from the port been obtained for the company's vehicles to enter and work inside it?
report2.item12: Is the specified speed adhered to and agreed upon with the employing company?
report2.item17: Administrative approval for the use of the railway line for coal transport
report2.item18: Coal loading stations contain a closed conveyor tube hopper
report2.item19: Is the cargo sprayed with sprayed water or chemicals to reach a moisture content of 10% to 15%?
report2.item20: Are the coal-carrying trains equipped with the necessary equipment and machinery for unloading coal in a way that reduces emissions risks in agreement with the Railway Authority?

report4.installationOfCoalTemperatureMonitoringS: Installation of coal temperature monitoring systems (portable - fixed)
report4.transportFromOpenYardToOperatingArea: Transport from open yard to operating area

report4.issuesToBeReportedAndInspectedAnnually: Issues to be reported and inspected annually for safety, and preparation of the inspection report
report4.safetySignsInDesignatedAreas: Are safety signs present in designated areas, are these signs clearly visible and readable with warnings of potential hazards when entering a coal or petroleum coke factory?
report4.accessToFireFightingEquipmentAndEmergenc: Is access to fire fighting equipment and emergency vehicles via at least two directions at all times?
report4.availabilityOfSafetyDataForCoalPetroleum: Is safety data available regarding coal/petroleum coke/AFR?
report4.strictProceduresForCoalHandling: Are strict procedures in place for coal handling?
report4.markingOfHazardousAreasOnSite: Are hazardous areas on site marked (yellow signs)?
report4.designatedHazardousAreasCovered: Are designated hazardous areas (at least one area or equivalent) covered so that layers (>1mm in thickness) regarding flammable dust, powder, or scatterable cover the entire area?
report4.equipmentComplianceWithHazardousAreaClas: Do installed equipment comply with hazardous area classification standards according to?
report4.appropriateEngineeringMeasuresForHandlin: Have appropriate engineering measures been taken to address accumulated layers of flammable dust in any of the internal structures?
report4.regularCleaningOfSiteIfPreventionIsNotFe: If prevention is not feasible, is the site cleaned regularly in an appropriate manner?
report4.installationOfFlameOrExplosionSuppressio: Have flame or explosion suppression systems been installed in necessary locations?
report4.appropriateEngineeringMeasuresToPreventO: Have appropriate engineering measures been identified to prevent or disperse static electricity charges (lightning protection, grounding...)
report4.installationOfLeakDetectionOutletsInCase: Have leak detection outlets been installed in case of explosions in necessary locations?
report4.installationOfFireDetectionAndAlarmSyste: Have fire detection and alarm devices been installed in all covered areas/narrow stores/handling areas/flammable coal processing areas/petroleum coke?
report4.appropriatenessOfFireDetectionSystemForH: Is the fire detection device suitable for the size and type of tasks being handled, and can this system be operated and available at all times?
report4.allFireDetectionDevicesConnectedToReliab: Are all fire detection devices connected to a reliable power source secure against faults?
report4.silosEquippedWithAppropriateFireExtingui: Are silos equipped with a suitable fire extinguishing/suppression system?
report4.areSilosEquippedWithCarbonMonoxideDetect: Are silos equipped with a carbon monoxide detection system?
report4.doCoalPetroleumDevicesHaveVaporInjection: Are coal/petroleum coke devices equipped with a vapor injection device (carbon dioxide/nitrogen)?
report4.isThereAnAppropriateFireFightingSystem: Is there an appropriate fire fighting system?
report4.areFireRiskConsiderationsTakenDuringMain: Are fire risk considerations taken into account during maintenance operations such as: using tools that do not produce sparks, safe lighting, and cleaning and scraping operations for floors and edges to prevent slipping (to prevent leakage) and periodic inspection using thermal imaging cameras (detecting hot loads) and continuous control and calibration of vital devices (carbon monoxide detection device) and that the magnetic insulator is working well...
report4.tableDescription: The table below illustrates the description of monitoring procedures including approvals in both cases for a list of equipment to be used and its specifications. The following table must be completed
report4.useOfPersonalProtectionEquipment: Use of personal protection equipment to protect workers
report4.useOfDustExtractionMachines: Use of dust extraction machines to prevent emissions of dust from coal
report4.useOfDisinfectionMachines: Use of disinfection machines on loaded coal on trucks to prevent hot spots formation
report4.floorCleaningAfterService: Cleaning of floors after service unloading and cleaning
report4.directUnloadingIntoTrucksOrConveyorBelts: Direct unloading into trucks or conveyor belts to reduce emissions resulting from reloading on trucks
report4.useOfWaterDisinfectionMachines: Use of water disinfection machines on coal in storage areas to prevent hot spots formation
report4.useOfCoveredConveyorBelts: Use of covered conveyor belts to reduce air emissions
report4.monitoringMeasurementAndCorrectiveAction: Monitoring, measurement, and corrective actions for air emissions reduction
report4.firstConveyorBeltRoom: Presence of first conveyor belt room to prevent the return of coal from the conveyor to reduce air emissions
report4.reportingViolations: In this regard, the company is required to report violations detected during inspections conducted by the Environmental Affairs Agency and the fines paid, as well as non-compliance issues and corrective actions taken.
report4.statementOfCoalShipments: Statement of coal shipments used, shipping companies and trucking companies contracted with
report4.environmentalApprovalForTruckingCompanie: Trucking companies are required to obtain an environmental approval issued based on a signed written commitment stating that the company will comply with the environmental requirements of the Environmental Affairs Agency regarding coal transportation. Any loading and unloading company must contract with a trucking company to ensure that it has an environmental approval
